name: wootils/browser/index.js
wootils/browser/simpleStorage.js

properties.name: warn
properties.description:
Prints out a warning message. Either this or `warning` MUST be
                              present.

properties.name: warning
properties.description:
Prints out a warning message. Either this or `warn` MUST be
                              present.

properties.name: name
properties.description: A reference name for the storage.

properties.name: key
properties.description:
The key the class will use to
                                                               store the data on the storage.

properties.name: typePriority
properties.description:
The priority list of types of
                                                               storage the service will try to
                                                               use when initialized.

properties.name: enabled
properties.description:
Whether or not to use the entries
                                                   functionality. Enabling it means that all
                                                   the _"xxxEntry"_ methods will be available
                                                   and that, when deleted or resetted, the
                                                   storage will become an empty object.

properties.name: expiration
properties.description:
The amount of seconds relative to the
                                                   current time that needs to pass in order to
                                                   consider an entry expired.

properties.name: deleteExpired
properties.description:
Whether or not to delete expired entries
                                                   (both when loading the storage and when
                                                   trying to access the entries).

properties.name: saveWhenDeletingExpired
properties.description:
Whether or not to sync the storage after
                                                   deleting an expired entry.

properties.name: initialize
properties.description:
Whether or not to initialize the
                                                          service right from the constructor.
                                                          It means that it will validate the
                                                          storage, check for existing data and
                                                          sync it on the class. This can be
                                                          disabled in case you need to do
                                                          something between the constructor and
                                                          the initialization.

properties.name: window
properties.description:
The `window`/`global` object the class
                                                          will use in order to access
                                                          `localStorage` and `sessionStorage`.

properties.name: logger
properties.description:
A custom logger to print out the
                                                          warnings when the class needs to do a
                                                          fallback to a different storage type.

properties.name: storage
properties.description:
These are all the options related to
                                                          the storage itself: The type, the
                                                          name and the key.

properties.name: entries
properties.description:
These are the options for customizing
                                                          the way the service works with entries.
                                                          By default, the class saves any kind
                                                          of object on the storage, but by
                                                          using entries you can access them by
                                                          name and even define expiration time
                                                          so they'll be removed after a while.

properties.name: tempStorage
properties.description:
The `tempStorage` is the storage the
                                                          class uses when none of the others
                                                          are available. Is just a simple
                                                          object, so when the class gets
                                                          destroyed (browser refreshes the
                                                          page), the data goes away.

params.name: fallbackFrom
params.description:
If the storage is being used as a fallback from another one that
                               is not available, this parameter will have its name.

return.description: Whether or not the storage is available.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used by the class to save data on the storage.

return.description: The contents from the storage.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used by the class to save data on the storage.

params.name: value
params.description: The data to save on the storage.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used by the class to save data on the storage.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the storage.

properties.name: available
properties.description:
The method to check if the storage can
                                                          be used or not.

properties.name: get
properties.description:
The method used to read from the
                                                          storage.

properties.name: set
properties.description:
The method used to write on the
                                                          storage.

properties.name: delete
properties.description:
The method used to delete data from
                                                          the storage.

properties.name: time
properties.description: The timestamp of when the entry was first created.

properties.name: value
properties.description: The actual data for the entry.

name: SimpleStorage
description:
An abstract class allows you to build services that relay on browser storage (session/local)
and simplifies the way you work it
You can specify the storage type you want to use, the format in which you want to handle the
data and even expiration time for it.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

params.name: options
params.description: The options to customize the class.

name: _options
description:
These are the options/settings the class uses in order to work the with the storage and
the data.

name: _storageTypes
description: A dictionary with the storage types the class supports.

properties.name: local
properties.description: The methods to work with `localStorage`.

properties.name: session
properties.description: The methods to work with `sessionStorage`.

properties.name: temp
properties.description: The methods to work with the _"temp storage"_.

name: _storage
description:
Once the class is initialized, this property will hold a reference to the
{@link SimpleStorageStorage} being used.

name: _data
description:
This is the object/dictionary the class will use to sync the content of the storage. That
way you won't need to write/read/parse from the storage every time you need to do something.

name: _initialize
description:
This method _"initializes" the class by validating custom options, loading the reference for
the required storage and synchronizing the data with the storage.

name: _getInitialData
description:
This method is called when the storage is deleted or resetted and if entries are disabled.
It can be used to define the initial value of the data the class saves on the storage.

name: _getData
description: Access the data the class saves on the storage.

name: _setData
description:
Overwrites the data reference the class has and, if `save` is used, it also saves it into
the storage.

params.name: data
params.description:
The new data, or a {@link Promise} that resolves into the
                                     new data.

params.name: save
params.description:
Whether or not the class should save the data into the
                                     storage.

return.description:
If `data` is an {@link Object}, it will return the same object; but
                         if `data` is a {@link Promise}, it will return the _"promise chain"_.

name: _setResolvedData
description:
This is the real method behind `_setData`. It overwrites the data reference the class
has and, if `save` is used, it also saves it into the storage.
The reason that there are two methods for this is, is because `_setData` can receive a
{@link Promise}, and in that case, this method gets called after it gets resolved.

params.name: data
params.description: The new data.

params.name: save
params.description: Whether or not the class should save the data into the storage.

return.description: The same data that was saved.

name: _resetData
description:
Resets the data on the class; If entries are enabled, the data will become an empty
{@link Object}; otherwise, it will call {@link this#_getInitialData}.

params.name: save
params.description: Whether or not the class should save the data into the storage.

name: _getEntry
description: Gets an entry from the storage dictionary.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

return.description: Whatever is on the storage.

name: _getEntryValue
description: Gets the value of an entry.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

name: _addEntry
description: Adds a new entry to the class data, and if `save` is used, saves it into the storage.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

params.name: value
params.description:
The entry value, or a {@link Promise} that resolves into
                                    the value.

params.name: save
params.description:
Whether or not the class should save the data into the
                                    storage.

return.description:
If `value` is an {@link Object}, it will return the same object; but
                         if `value` is a {@link Promise}, it will return the
                         _"promise chain"_.

name: _addResolvedEntry
description:
This is the real method behind `_addEntry`. It Adds a new entry to the class data and, if
`save` is used, it also saves it into the storage.
The reason that there are two methods for this is, is because `_addEntry` can receive a
{@link Promise}, and in that case, this method gets called after it gets resolved.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

params.name: value
params.description: The entry value.

params.name: save
params.description: Whether or not the class should save the data into the storage.

return.description: The same data that was saved.

name: _deleteEntry
description:
Deletes an entry from the class data, and if `save` is used, the changes will be saved on
the storage.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

params.name: save
params.description:
Whether or not the class should save the data into the storage
                             after deleting the entry.

return.description: Whether or not the entry was deleted.

name: _hasEntry
description: Checks whether an entry exists or not.

params.name: key
params.description: The entry key.

name: _delete
description: Deletes the class data from the storage.

params.name: reset
params.description:
Whether or not to reset the data to the initial data
                              (`_getInitialData`), if entries area disabled, or to an empty
                              object, if they are enabled.

name: _save
description: Saves the data from the class into the storage.

name: _mergeOptions
description:
Merges the class default options with the custom ones that can be sent to the constructor.
The reason there's a method for this is because some of the options can be functions, and
deep merges with functions can go wrong (and are expensive), so this methods takes out the
functions first, does the merge and then adds them again.
Similar to what it does for fuctions, it also takes out arrays: Merging arrays not always work
as expected if the base array has some values already. Instead of the base values being
overwritten, they are replaced with the amount of values specified on the _"overwrite array"_.
Is easy to understand the reason, but nonetheless, it makes it confussing for an option to
behave like that.

params.name: defaults
params.description: The class default options.

params.name: custom
params.description: The custom options sent to the constructor.

name: _validateOptions
description: Validates the class options before loading the storage and the data.

throws.description: If either `storage.name` or `storage.key` are missing from the options.

If the options have a custom logger but it doesn't have `warn` nor `warning`
                methods.

name: _initializeStorage
description:
This method checks the list of priorities from the `storage.typePriority` option and tries
to find the first available storage.

throws.description: If none of the storage options are available.

name: _initializeStorageData
description:
Initializes the data on the class and if needed, on the storage. It first tries to load
existing data from the storage, if there's nothing, it just sets an initial stage; but if
there was something on the storage, and entries are enabled, it will try (if also enabled)
to delete expired entries.

name: _deleteExpiredEntries
description: Filters out a dictionary of entries by checking if they expired or not.

params.name: entries
params.description:
A dictionary of key-value, where the value is a
                            {@link SimpleStorageEntry}.

params.name: expiration
params.description:
The amount of seconds that need to have passed in order to
                            consider an entry expired.

return.description: A new dictionary without the expired entries.

name: _warn
description:
Prints out a warning message. The method will first check if there's a custom logger (from
the class options), otherwise, it will fallback to the `console` on the `window` option.

params.name: message
params.description: The message to print out.

name: _copy
description: Makes a deep copy of an object.

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to copy.

name: _now
description: Helper method to get the current timestamp in seconds.

name: _isPromise
description: Checkes whether an object is a Promise or not.

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to test.

name: _warnStorageFallback
description:
Prints out a message saying that the class is doing a fallback from a storage to another
one.

params.name: from
params.description: The name of the storage that's not available.

params.name: to
params.description: The name of the storage that will be used instead.

name: _isLocalStorageAvailable
description: Checks whether `localStorage` is available or not.

params.name: fallbackFrom
params.description:
In case it's being used as a fallback, this will be the name
                               of the storage that wasn't available.

name: _getFromLocalStorage
description: Gets an object from `localStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used to save the object.

name: _setOnLocalStorage
description: Sets an object into the `localStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

params.name: value
params.description: The object to save.

name: _deleteFromLocalStorage
description: Deletes an object from the `localStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

name: _isSessionStorageAvailable
description: Checks whether `sessionStorage` is available or not.

params.name: fallbackFrom
params.description:
In case it's being used as a fallback, this will be the name
                               of the storage that wasn't available.

name: _getFromSessionStorage
description: Gets an object from `sessionStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used to save the object.

name: _setOnSessionStorage
description: Sets an object into the `sessionStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

params.name: value
params.description: The object to save.

name: _deleteFromSessionStorage
description: Deletes an object from the `sessionStorage`.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

name: _isTempStorageAvailable
description:
This method is just here to comply with the {@link SimpleStorageStorage} _"interface"_ as
the temp storage is always available.

params.name: fallbackFrom
params.description:
In case it's being used as a fallback, this will be the name
                               of the storage that wasn't available.

name: _getFromTempStorage
description: Gets an object from the _"temp storage"_.

params.name: key
params.description: The key used to save the object.

name: _setOnTempStorage
description: Sets an object into the _"temp storage"_.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

params.name: value
params.description: The object to save.

name: _deleteFromTempStorage
description: Deletes an object from the _"temp storage"_.

params.name: key
params.description: The object key.

name: wootils/node/appConfiguration.js

properties.name: defaultConfigurationName
properties.description:
The name of the default
                                                                  configuration

properties.name: environmentVariable
properties.description:
The name of the variable it
                                                                  will read in order to
                                                                  determine which configuration
                                                                  to load

properties.name: path
properties.description:
The path to the configurations
                                                                  directory, relative to the
                                                                  project root path.

properties.name: filenameFormat
properties.description:
The name format of the
                                                                  configuration files. You
                                                                  need to use the `[name]`
                                                                  placeholder so the service
                                                                  can replace it with the name
                                                                  of the configuration.

name: AppConfiguration
description:
This is a service to manage applications configurations. It takes care of loading, activating,
switching and merging configuration files.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

params.name: environmentUtils
params.description:
Required to read the environment
                                                           variables and determine which
                                                           configuration to use.

params.name: rootRequire
params.description:
Necessary to be able to require the
                                                           configuration files with paths
                                                           relative to the app root directory.

params.name: appName
params.description:
The name of the app using this
                                                           service.
                                                           It's also used as part of the name
                                                           of the configuration files.

params.name: defaultConfiguration
params.description:
The default configuration the others
                                                           will extend.

params.name: options
params.description: Options to customize the service

name: environmentUtils
description: A local reference for the `environmentUtils` service.

name: rootRequire
description:
The function that allows the service to `require` a configuration file with a path relative
to the app root directory.

name: options
description: The service customizable options.

name: configurations
description:
A dictionary with all the loaded configurations. It uses the names of the configurations
as keys.

name: activeConfiguration
description: The name of the active configuration.

name: allowConfigurationSwitch
description: Whether or not the configuration can be switched.

name: load
description: Load a new configuration.

params.name: name
params.description: The configuration name.

params.name: settings
params.description: The configuration settings.

params.name: switchTo
params.description:
If the service should switch to the new configuration after
                                 adding it.

return.description: The settings of the new configuration.

throws.description: If the configuration tries to extend a configuration that doesn't exist.

name: loadFromFile
description: Load a configuration from a file.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the configuration.

params.name: switchTo
params.description:
If the service should switch to the new configuration
                                        after adding it.

params.name: checkSwitchFlag
params.description:
If `true`, the service will update the value of
                                        `allowConfigurationSwitch` based on the loaded
                                        configuration setting.

return.description: The settings of the loaded configuration.

throws.description: If the configuration file can't be loaded.

name: loadFromEnvironment
description:
Check if there's a configuration name on the environment variable and if there is, try to load
the configuration file for it.

return.description: The loaded configuration or an empty object if the variable was empty.

name: getConfig
description:
Get a configuration settings. If no name is specified, it will return the settings of the
default configuration.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the configuration.

name: get
description: Get a setting or settings from the active configuration.

params.name: setting
params.description: The name of a setting or a list of them.

name: set
description:
Set the value of a setting or settings from the active configuration.
If both the current and the new value of a setting are objects, then instead of overwriting
it, the method will merge them.

params.name: setting
params.description:
The name of the setting to update or a dictionary of settings
                               and their values.

params.name: value
params.description:
The value of the setting. This is only used when `setting` is
                               a string.

name: canSwitch
description: Check whether the service can switch configurations or not.

name: switch
description:
Switch to a different configuration. If the configuration is not registered, it will try to
load from a file.

params.name: name
params.description: The new of the configuration to switch to.

params.name: force
params.description:
A way to force the service to switch even if the
                               `allowConfigurationSwitch` property if `false`.

return.description: The new active configuration.

throws.description: If `force` is `false` and the `allowConfigurationSwitch` property is `false`.

name: _addConfiguration
description: Add a new configuration to the service.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the new configuration.

params.name: settings
params.description: The configuration settings.

params.name: checkSwitchFlag
params.description:
Whether or not the `allowConfigurationSwitch` should be
                                 updated with the value of this new configuration setting.

params.name: switchTo
params.description:
Whether or not to switch it to the active configuration
                                 after adding it.

name: appConfiguration
description: Generates a `Provider` with an already defined name, default configuration and options.

params.name: appName
params.description: The name of the app.

params.name: defaultConfiguration
params.description: The service default configuration.

params.name: options
params.description: Options to customize the service.

name: wootils/node/environmentUtils.js
EnvironmentUtils
description: A simple service to avoid calling `process.env` on multiples places of an app.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

name: env
description: The current `NODE_ENV`. If the variable is empty, the value will be `development`.

name: production
description: Whether or not the environment is production.

name: get
description: Get the value of an environment variable.
todo: add a `require` parameter to throw an error if the variable is not preset.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the variable.

params.name: defaultValue
params.description: A fallback value in case the variable is `undefined`

name: development
description: Check whether or not the environment is for development.

name: environmentUtils
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set an instance of
`EnvironmentUtils` as the `environmentUtils` service.

name: wootils/node/errorHandler.js
ErrorHandler
description:
An error handler that captures uncaught exceptions and unhandled rejections in order to log
them with detail.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

params.name: appLogger
params.description: To log the detail of the erros.

params.name: exitOnError
params.description:
Whether or not to exit the process after receiving an
                                    error.

name: appLogger
description: A local reference for the `appLogger` service.

name: exitOnError
description: Whether or not to exit the process after receiving an error.

name: eventsNames
description: The list of events this handler will listen for in order to catch errors.

name: handler
description: Bind the handler method so it can be used on the calls to `process`.

name: listen
description: Starts listening for unhandled errors.

name: stopListening
description: Stops listening for unhandled errors.

name: handle
description:
This is called by the process listeners when an uncaught exception is thrown or a rejected
promise is not handled. It logs the error on detail.
The process exits when after logging an error.

params.name: error
params.description: The unhandled error.

name: errorHandlerWithOptions
description:
Generates a `Provider` with an already defined flag to exit or not the process when after
handling an error.

params.name: exitOnError
params.description: Whether or not to exit the process after receiving an error.

name: errorHandler
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set an instance of
`ErrorHandler` as the `errorHandler` service.

name: wootils/node/index.js
wootils/node/logger.js
Logger
description: A utility service to log messages on the console.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

params.name: messagesPrefix
params.description: A prefix to include in front of all the messages.

params.name: showTime
params.description: Whether or not to show the time on each message.

name: messagesPrefix
description: The prefix to include in front of all the messages.

name: showTime
description: Whether or not to show the time on each message.

name: warning
description: Logs a warning (yellow) message or messages on the console.

params.name: message
params.description:
A single message of a list of them. See the `log()` documentation
                              to see all the supported properties for the `message` parameter.

name: success
description: Logs a success (green) message or messages on the console.

params.name: message
params.description:
A single message of a list of them. See the `log()` documentation
                              to see all the supported properties for the `message` parameter.

name: error
description: Logs an error (red) message or messages on the console.

params.name: message
params.description:
A single message of a list of them. See the
                                             `log()` documentation to see all the supported
                                             properties for the `message` parameter. Different
                                             from the other log methods, you can use an
                                             `Error` object and the method will take care of
                                             extracting the message and the stack information.

params.name: exception
params.description:
If the exception has a `stack` property, the
                                             method will log each of the stack calls using
                                             `info()`.

name: info
description: Logs an information (gray) message or messages on the console.

params.name: message
params.description:
A single message of a list of them. See the `log()` documentation
                              to see all the supported properties for the `message` parameter.

name: log
description: Logs a message with an specific color on the console.

params.name: message
params.description: A text message to log or a list of them.

params.name: color
params.description:
Optional. The color of the message (the default is 'white').
                              This can be overwritten line by line when the message is an
                              array, take a look at the example.

name: prefix
description: Prefixes a message with the text sent to the constructor and, if enabled, the current time.

params.name: text
params.description: The text that needs the prefix.

name: _color
description:
Gets a function to modify the color of a string. The reason for this _"proxy method"_ is that
the `colors` module doesn't have a `raw` option and the alternative would've been adding a few
`if`s on the `log` method.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the color.

return.description: A function that receives a string and returns it colored.

name: loggerWithOptions
description: Generates a `Provider` with an already defined message prefix and time setting.

params.name: messagesPrefix
params.description: A prefix to include in front of all the messages.

params.name: showTime
params.description: Whether or not to show the time on each message.

name: logger
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set an instance of
`Logger` as the `logger` service.

name: appLoggerWithOptions
description:
Generates a `Provider` with an already defined time setting and that uses the `packageInfo`
service in order to retrieve the name of the project and use it as messages prefix.

params.name: showTime
params.description: Whether or not to show the time on each message.

name: appLogger
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set an instance of
`Logger` as the `appLogger` service. The difference with the regular `logger` is that this one
uses the `packageInfo` service in order to retrieve the name of the project and use it as
messages prefix.

name: wootils/node/packageInfo.js
packageInfo
description: Returns the contents of the project `package.json`.

params.name: pathUtils
params.description: To build the path to the `package.json`.

name: packageInfoProvider
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set the result of
`packageInfo()` as the `packageInfo` service.

name: wootils/node/pathUtils.js
PathUtils
description:
A utility services to manage paths on a project. It allows for path building relatives to
the project root or from where the app executable is located.

name: constructor
description: Class constructor.

params.name: home
params.description:
The location of the project's `home`(root) directory. By default
                          it uses `process.cwd()`.

name: path
description: The root path from where the app is being executed.

name: locations
description: A dictionary of different path locations.

name: addLocation
description: Add a new location.

params.name: name
params.description: The reference name.

params.name: locationPath
params.description:
The path of the location. It must be inside the path from the
                             app is being executed.

name: getLocation
description: Get a location path by its name.

params.name: name
params.description: The location name.

throws.description: If there location hasn't been added.

name: joinFrom
description: Build a path using a location path as base.

params.name: location
params.description: The location name.

params.name: paths
params.description: The rest of the path components to join.

name: join
description: Alias to `joinFrom` that uses the `home` location by default.

params.name: paths
params.description: The rest of the path components to join.

name: home
description: Get the project root path.

name: app
description: Get the path to the directory where the app executable is located.

name: _addAppLocation
description: Find and register the location for the app executable directory.

name: pathUtils
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set an instance of
`PathUtils` as the `pathUtils` service.

name: pathUtilsWithHome
description: Generates a `Provider` with an already defined `home` location.

params.name: home
params.description: The path to the new home location.

name: wootils/node/providers.js
wootils/node/rootRequire.js
rootRequire
description: Generates a function to require a file relative to the project root directory.

params.name: pathUtils
params.description: To build the path to the files it will `require`.

name: rootRequireProvider
description:
The service provider that once registered on the app container will set the result of
`rootRequire(pathUtils)` as the `rootRequire` service.

name: wootils/node/typedef.js
content:
/**
 * @external {Jimple}
 * https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/jimple
 */

/**
 * @typedef {function} ProviderRegisterMethod
 * @param {Jimple} app
 * A reference to the dependency injection container.
 */

/**
 * @typedef {Object} Provider
 * @property {ProviderRegisterMethod} register
 * The method that gets called when registering the provider.
 */

properties.description: The method that gets called when registering the provider.

If `event` was a `string`, it will return whether or not the listener
                        was found and removed; but if `event` was an `Array`, it will return
                        a list of boolean values.

name: emit
description: Emits an event and call all its listeners.

params.name: event
params.description: An event name or a list of them.

params.name: args

name: reduce
description:
Reduce a target using an event. It's like emit, but the events listener return
a modified (or not) version of the `target`.

params.description: An event name or a list of them.

params.name: target
params.description: The variable to reduce with the listeners.

return.description: A version of the `target` processed by the listeners.

name: subscribers
description: Get all the listeners for an event.

params.name: event
params.description: The name of the event.

name: wootils/shared/index.js
wootils/shared/objectUtils.js
ObjectUtils
description: A small collection of utility methods to work with objects.

throws.description: is called. This class is meant to be have only static methods.

name: merge
description: This method makes a deep merge of a list of objects into a new one.

params.name: targets
params.description: The objects to merge.

name: copy
description: Creates a deep copy of a given object.

params.name: target
params.description: The object to copy.

name: get
description: Returns the value of an object property using a path.

params.name: target
params.description: The object from where the property will be read.

params.name: objPath
params.description: The path to the property.

params.name: pathDelimiter
params.description: The delimiter that will separate the path components.

params.name: failWithError
params.description:
Whether or not to throw an error when the path is
                                       invalid. If this is `false`, the method will silently
                                       fail and return `undefined`.

throws.description: If the path is invalid and `failWithError` is set to `true`.

name: set
description: Sets a property on an object using a path. If the path doesn't exist, it will be created.

params.name: target
params.description: The object where the property will be set.

params.name: objPath
params.description: The path for the property.

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set on the property.

params.name: pathDelimiter
params.description: The delimiter that will separate the path components.

params.name: failWithError
params.description:
Whether or not to throw an error when the path is
                                       invalid. If this is `false`, the method will silently
                                       fail and return `undefined`.

return.description: A copy of the original object with the added property/properties.

throws.description:
If one of the path components is for a non-object property and
                `failWithError` is set to `true`.

name: extract
description: Extracts a property or properties from an object in order to create a new one.

params.name: target
params.description:
The object from where the
                                                   property/properties will be extracted.

params.name: objPaths
params.description:
This can be a single path or a list of
                                                   them. And for this method, the paths are
                                                   not only strings but can also be an object
                                                   with a single key, the would be the path
                                                   to where to "do the extraction", and the
                                                   value the path on the target object.

params.name: pathDelimiter
params.description:
The delimiter that will separate the
                                                   path components.

params.name: failWithError
params.description:
Whether or not to throw an error when the
                                                   path is invalid. If this is `false`, the
                                                   method will silently fail an empty object.

name: delete
description: Deletes a property of an object using a path.

params.name: target
params.description:
The object from where the property will be
                                             removed.

params.name: objPath
params.description: The path to the property.

params.name: pathDelimiter
params.description:
The delimiter that will separate the path
                                             components.

params.name: cleanEmptyProperties
params.description:
If this flag is `true` and after removing the
                                             property the parent object is empty, it will
                                             remove it recursively until a non empty parent
                                             object is found.

params.name: failWithError
params.description:
Whether or not to throw an error when the path
                                             is invalid. If this is `false`, the method will
                                             silently fail.

return.description: A copy of the original object with the removed property/properties.

content:
# Wootils

[![Travis](https://img.shields.io/travis/homer0/wootils.svg?style=flat-square)](https://travis-ci.org/homer0/wootils)
[![Coveralls github](https://img.shields.io/coveralls/github/homer0/wootils.svg?style=flat-square)](https://coveralls.io/github/homer0/wootils?branch=master)
[![David](https://img.shields.io/david/homer0/wootils.svg?style=flat-square)](https://david-dm.org/homer0/wootils)
[![David](https://img.shields.io/david/dev/homer0/wootils.svg?style=flat-square)](https://david-dm.org/homer0/wootils)

A set of Javascript utilities for building Node and browser apps.

## Motivation/Introduction

The idea was to take all those small thing I'm always rewriting on every project and move them to a single package so I can not only stop copying & pasting them all over the place but also maintain them all together.

There are two rules I followed when I had to decide what to put and what to keep somewhere else:

1. The utility needs to fit on a single file.
2. It shouldn't include any specific business logic from any other project.

## Information

| -            | -                                                                  |
|--------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Package      | wootils                                                            |
| Description  | A set of Javascript utilities for building Node and browser apps.  |
| Node Version | >= v8.0.0                                                         |

## Usage

The package is divided on 3 folders:

- `node`: Utilities that are only compatible with Node.
- `shared`: Utilities that can work on both browser and Node.
- `browser`: Utilities that can only be used while on a browser.

### Node utilities

Two notes about the Node utilities:

1. I'm a big fan of [Jimple](https://github.com/fjorgemota/jimple), so all the files not only export the utility but also a service provider or a _"servicer provider generator"_ to register the utility on a Jimple app.
2. Some of them may depend on the others.

#### AppConfiguration

This is a service to manage applications configurations. It takes care of loading, activating, switching and merging configuration files.

[Read more about AppConfiguration](manual/appConfiguration.html)

#### EnvironmentUtils

A really small service to centralize the place where you read environment variables and check if you are running on development or production.

[Read more about EnvironmentUtils](manual/environmentUtils.html)

#### ErrorHandler

Listens for uncaught exceptions and unhandled promises rejections, and logs them out with full detail.

[Read more about ErrorHandler](manual/errorHandler.html)

#### Logger

The name leaves nothing to the imagination. As you may have guessed, this is service for logging messages into the console.

[Read more about Logger](manual/logger.html)

#### packageInfo

A tiny function that reads the contents of the app `package.json`. This is really useful on an Jimple application where you can register it, because the returned value gets cached and it's available as a service.

[Read more about packageInfo](manual/packageInfo.html)

#### PathUtils

An easy way to manage locations and build paths relative to those locations on a Node app.

[Read more about PathUtils](manual/pathUtils.html)

#### rootRequire

Is basically `require` but the path is relative to the project root directory.

[Read more about rootRequire](manual/rootRequire.html)

### Shared utilities

#### APIClient

A really basic client to work with an API endpoints requests.

[Read more about APIClient](manual/APIClient.html)

#### deferred

Create a deferred promise using the native `Promise` object.

[Read more about deferred](manual/deferred.html)

#### EventsHub

A small implementation of a pubsub service for handling events on an app.

[Read more about EventsHub](manual/eventsHub.html)

#### ObjectUtils

A small collection of utility methods to work with objects.

[Read more about ObjectUtils](manual/objectUtils.html)

### Browser utilities

#### SimpleStorage

An **abstract** class allows you to build services that relay on browser storage (session/local) and simplifies the way you work it.

[Read more about SimpleStorage](manual/simpleStorage.html)

## Development

Before doing anything, install the repository hooks:

```bash
# You can either use npm or yarn, it doesn't matter
yarn run hooks
```

### NPM/Yarn Tasks

| Task                     | Description                         |
|--------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| `yarn run hooks`         | Install the GIT repository hooks.   |
| `yarn test`              | Run the project unit tests.         |
| `yarn run lint`          | Lint the modified files.            |
| `yarn run lint:full`     | Lint the project code.              |
| `yarn run docs`          | Generate the project documentation. |
| `yarn run todo`          | List all the pending to-do's.       |

### Testing

I use [Jest](https://facebook.github.io/jest/) with [Jest-Ex](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/jest-ex) to test the project. The configuration file is on `./.jestrc`, the tests and mocks are on `./tests` and the script that runs it is on `./utils/scripts/test`.

### Linting

I use [ESlint](http://eslint.org) to validate all our JS code. The configuration file for the project code is on `./.eslintrc` and for the tests on `./tests/.eslintrc` (which inherits from the one on the root), there's also an `./.eslintignore` to ignore some files on the process, and the script that runs it is on `./utils/scripts/lint`.

### Documentation

I use [ESDoc](http://esdoc.org) to generate HTML documentation for the project. The configuration file is on `./.esdocrc` and the script that runs it is on `./utils/scripts/docs`.

### To-Dos

I use `@todo` comments to write all the pending improvements and fixes, and [Leasot](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/leasot) to generate a report. The script that runs it is on `./utils/scripts/todo`.
name: ./README-esdoc.md

  }
}
name: package.json
./documents/node/appConfiguration.md
./documents/node/environmentUtils.md
./documents/node/errorHandler.md
content:
# ErrorHandler

Listens for uncaught exceptions and unhandled promises rejections, and logs them out with full detail.

By default, if an error is thrown, node will just output the error, but if a `Promise` is rejected and there's no `catch` to capture the exception, it will log `...`, which doesn't provide a lot of information, right?

Well, `ErrorHandler` listens for these kind of exceptions, unhandled errors and rejected promises, and logs them with their stack trace information using the `Logger` utility.

## Example

Let's say your code looks something like this:

```js
makeAnAPICall()
.then((response) => console.log(response));
```

If the request returned a `401`, Node would output something like this:

```bash
(node:34097) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 2): 401
```

Now, let's see how to get more information with `ErrorHandler`:

> The service depends on a `Logger` service instance, so you need to register it first.

### Without Jimple

> If you haven't tried [Jimple](https://github.com/fjorgemota/jimple), give it a try, it's excellent for organizing your app dependencies and services.

Let's start with the setup:

> All of this code should be added on top of the already existing code showed above.

```js
const { Logger, ErrorHandler } = require('wootils/node');
// Create an instance of the logger service
const logger = new Logger();
// Create an instance of the handler
const errorHandler = new ErrorHandler(logger);
```

Now, once you have the instance, you have to tell it to start listening for unhandled errors:

```js
errorHandler.listen();
```

Done! If you run the same code now, this is the kind of logged information you'll get:

```bash
[2018-01-22 04:19:12] 401
at makeAPICall (/path-to-your-app/index.js:9:42)
at Object.<anonymous> (/path-to-your-app/index.js:11:1)
at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
at Module.runMain (module.js:604:10)
at run (bootstrap_node.js:383:7)
at startup (bootstrap_node.js:149:9)
```

You get the date and time when it happened and the full stack trace of the error.

### With Jimple

When used with Jimple, instead of using the `logger` service, it uses the `logger` service:

> It uses `logger` by default, but if the service is not available, it will try to fallback to `appLogger`, the alternative version of `logger` that prefixes all the messages with the project name.

```js
// Import all the required modules
const Jimple = require('jimple');
const {
  logger,
  errorHandler,
} = require('wootils/node/providers');
// Create a dummy app
const app = new Jimple();
// Register the logger
app.register(logger);
// Register the ErrorHandler
app.register(errorHandler);
```
Now, we should tell the service to start listening for errors:

```js
app.get('errorHandler').listen();
```

Done! If you run the same code now, this is the kind of logged information you'll get:

```bash
[my-app] [2018-01-22 04:29:40] 401
[my-app] at makeAPICall (/path-to-your-app/index.js:9:42)
[my-app] at Object.<anonymous> (/path-to-your-app/index.js:11:1)
[my-app] at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
[my-app] at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
[my-app] at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
[my-app] at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
[my-app] at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)
[my-app] at Module.runMain (module.js:604:10)
[my-app] at run (bootstrap_node.js:383:7)
[my-app] at startup (bootstrap_node.js:149:9)
```

## Technical documentation

The code is fully documented with [ESDoc](https://esdoc.org) and you can either read the generated documentation [online](https://homer0.github.io/wootils/class/wootils/node/errorHandler.js~ErrorHandler.html) and generate it yourself using:

```bash
# You can either use npm or yarn, it doesn't matter
npm run docs
open ./docs/index.html
```

name: ./documents/node/logger.md
./documents/node/packageInfo.md
./documents/node/pathUtils.md
content:
# PathUtils

An easy way to manage locations and build paths relative to those locations on a Node app.

When writing static `require` statements is easy: The file you are requiring is relative to the one where you are writing the `require`. But when you are reading files or doing `require` with dynamic paths, it can get messy pretty fast, and that's where this utility shines.

## Example

Let's say your app tree looks like this:

```
myApp/
 config/
    development.js
    production.js
 app/
     index.js
```

And you want to access `config/development.js`, but when you build your app, or prepare it to deployment, it becomes this:

```
myApp/
 dist/
    app/
        index.min.js
 config/
    development.js
    production.js
 app/
     index.js
```

There's a lot of ways to check whether you need to call `../config` or `../../config`: `TryCatch`, check some environment variable, check if `../config` exists, etc. Well, with `PathUtils`, you don't need to do that, because the service knowns that if you ask for `config/development.js`, it's relative to your project root directory.

### Without Jimple

> If you haven't tried [Jimple](https://github.com/fjorgemota/jimple), give it a try, it's excellent for organizing your app dependencies and services.

```js
// Require the class.
const { PathUtils } = require('wootils/node');
// Instantiate it.
const pathUtils = new PathUtils();
```

Now that you have the service instance, getting the path is easy as:

```js
const devConfigPath = pathUtils.join('config/development');
```

Done, now you can use either `require` or `fs` to get the contents of the file.

### With Jimple

```js
// Import all the required modules
const Jimple = require('jimple');
const { pathUtils } = require('wootils/node/providers');
// Create a dummy app
const app = new Jimple();
// Register the service
app.register(pathUtils);
```

Now that you have the service instance, getting the path is easy as:

```js
const devConfigPath = app.get('pathUtils').join('config/development');
```

Done, now you can use either `require` or `fs` to get the contents of the file.

## Features

### Build paths relative to the project root directory

This was demonstrated on the example above. The `join` method works exactly like `path.join`, you can send any number of parameters and they will be merged on one single path.

```js
pathUtils.join('config', 'development.js');
// is the same as
pathUtils.join('config/development.js');
```

### Multiple locations

By default, `PathUtils` uses the `home` location, which is the project root directory, but it also has an `app` location and the ability to register new locations:

The `app` location is the directory where your app executable file is located, for the project tree used on the example above, the `app` location is `/app` on development, and `/dist/app` when builded/deployed.

To register new locations, you use the `addLocation` method:

```js
pathUtils.addLocation('my-location', 'some-folder/some-sub-folder');
```

The new location path **must** be relative to your project root directory.

And finally, to use those locations, you use `joinFrom` instead of `join`:

```js
const pathToFile = pathUtils.joinFrom('my-location', 'some-file.js');
```

## Technical documentation

The code is fully documented with [ESDoc](https://esdoc.org) and you can either read the generated documentation [online](https://homer0.github.io/wootils/class/wootils/node/pathUtils.js~PathUtils.html) or generate it yourself using:

```bash
# You can either use npm or yarn, it doesn't matter
npm run docs
open ./docs/index.html
```

name: ./documents/node/rootRequire.md
content:
# rootRequire

Is basically `require` but the path is relative to the project root directory.

This is very useful when working with dynamic `require` statements and project that when bundled or deployed change locations.

## Example

Let's say your app tree looks like this:

```
myApp/
 config/
    development.js
    production.js
 app/
     index.js
```

And you want to access `config/development.js`, but when you build your app, or prepare it to deployment, it becomes this:

```
myApp/
 dist/
    app/
        index.min.js
 config/
    development.js
    production.js
 app/
     index.js
```

There's a lot of ways to check whether you need to call `../config` or `../../config`: `TryCatch`, check some environment variable, check if `../config` exists, etc.  Well, with `rootRequire`, you don't need to do that, because the service knowns that if you ask for `config/development.js`, it's relative to your project root directory.

Now, before taking a look a how we would implement this with root require, the function, even as small as it is, it has a dependency: `PathUtils`. It uses it to build the paths relative to the project root directory.

### Without Jimple

> If you haven't tried [Jimple](https://github.com/fjorgemota/jimple), give it a try, it's excellent for organizing your app dependencies and services.

Let's start with the setup:

```js
const { PathUtils, rootRequire } = require('wootils/node');
// Create an instance of the dependency.
const pathUtils = new PathUtils();

// Now, let's generate the function
const rootReq = rootRequire(pathUtils);
// And finally use it to get the file
const config = rootReq('config/development');
```

Done, `config` now has the contents of `config/development`, and this will work no matter where the app file is located.

### With Jimple

First, let's setup a dummy app and register the dependency and the service itself:

```js
// Import all the required modules
const Jimple = require('jimple');
const { pathUtils, rootRequire } = require('wootils/node/providers');
// Create a dummy app
const app = new Jimple();
// Register the dependency
app.register(pathUtils);
// Register the service
app.register(rootRequire);
```

Now, to use it:

```js
const config = app.get('rootRequire')('config/development');
```

Done, `config` now has the contents of `config/development`, and this will work no matter where the app file is located.

## Technical documentation

The code is fully documented with [ESDoc](https://esdoc.org) and you can either read the generated documentation [online](https://homer0.github.io/wootils/function/index.html#static-function-rootRequire) or generate it yourself using:

```bash
# You can either use npm or yarn, it doesn't matter
npm run docs
open ./docs/index.html
```
